CARGO CONTAINERS UNLOADED ON WEST COAST HELD HUMAN CARGO _ CHINESE
STOWAWAYS 

  (ART ADV: A photo is being sent. Non-subscribers can purchase by
calling 888-603-1036 or 888-346-9867.) 
(DW) 
 By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   SEATTLE _ Accommodations for the 15-day trip from Hong Kong were
a metal cargo container, covered by canvas and stacked atop several
other such tractor-trailer-size boxes in the hold of a giant
freighter called the Cape May. The only light was from flashlights.
Human waste was deposited in buckets. Food, primarily boxes of
vegetables, ran out at some point. The seas were particularly
rough.

   When the Cape May pulled into Seattle and the containers were
taken off late Monday afternoon, 15 men from China stumbled out of
the metal box, dazed, dehydrated and gravely hungry. The stowaways,
illegal immigrants who had agreed to pay tens of thousands of
dollars in future wages to smugglers, pointed to the garbage-strewn
container, indicating even grimmer news. Inside were the bodies of
three men who had died during the crossing.

   ``These containers were designed to carry machinery and cargo _
not people,'' said Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the Immigration
and Naturalization Service. ``The people aboard the Cape May were
effectively entombed.''

   At least 10 times in recent weeks, officials at ports on the
west coast of the United States and Canada have found human beings
in cargo containers, a reflection of an alarming new trend in
smuggling that has now turned deadly and of the extraordinary steps
that Chinese laborers are willing to take to reach North America
and the jobs they are promised here.

   There are almost certainly more instances in which such
travelers have managed to make it across without detection, as some
freighters carry 1,000 containers or more. There is no question
that more such human-laden boxes are on the way, officials say. At
5 a.m. Tuesday, another 19 Chinese men, all relatively young and in
apparent good health, were discovered in a cargo container aboard
the Hanjin Yokohma, which had also sailed from Hong Kong. With
American and Canadian officials expressing shock at the recent
discoveries, Hong Kong authorities pledged a crackdown Tuesday on
the illegal trafficking, which has been detected so far in
freighters arriving here and in Long Beach, Calif., and Vancouver,
B.C. Conditions in the containers vary widely: some, with
ventilation punched through the canvas tops and with furniture and
electric heaters and lights, seem to be somewhat endurable. But in
other cases, particularly aboard the Cape May, they are
nightmarish.

   Said Bob Coleman, the acting director of the immigration service
in Seattle, of the Cape May stowaways: ``I've simply never seen
people so disoriented, so distraught.''

   It is not clear yet whether the three dead people aboard the
freighter perished from exposure to the cold in their unheated
containers, lack of water, or perhaps a combination of the two,
officials said Tuesday.

   Of the 15 who survived the journey in the 40-foot-long, 8-foot
wide metal box, seven remain in Harborview Medical Center in
satisfactory condition, all being treated for dehydration or
malnutrition, said Larry Zalin, a spokesman for the hospital. Eight
others, able to eat solid food, were released Tuesday into the
custody of the immigration service.

   Under American immigration laws, unless they can establish a
well-grounded fear of persecution in their native country, the
stowaways will likely be deported to China in weeks. In recent
days, U. S. authorities have repatriated at least 246 recent
stowaways to China, some who arrived in containers and others
elsewhere on ships.

   American officials hope that word of the repatriations may deter
others from making the hazardous journeys, but such actions have
hardly stemmed the tide in the past. As unemployment increases in
China and the demand for cheap labor continues in this country,
some experts think it will only increase.
